header: Routes where trains travel back and forth on the same track.

header: Neighborhoods that have a circular grid pattern.

name: Greenhouses
notes: Significant indoor botanical gardens.

header: Lines where trains reverse direction to gain altitude.

footer: See an analysis of confluence points in countries.
header: Points on earth where lines of latitude and longitude intersect!
name: Confluence Points
notes: A former manager of mine thought I would be into this, and it turned into an obsession!
Source data from confluence.org, which has pages for most points on or near land.
I've gone on several road trips with the goal of visiting many confluence points.
I have good coverage of a good part of northeastern United States and north-central Europe.
I've been to every point in several states and countries.

header: Stations where metro services sometimes turn around early to maintain higher frequency on part of the line.

header: Forts and other structures whose primary purpose is defensive.

header: Pairs of metro stations that are unusally close together.

header: Metro stations where the primary access is by elevator.
name: Elevator Stations

header: Locations where live albums were recorded.
name: Live

header: Metro stations with platforms that are not directly opposite one another.
name: Offset Platforms

header: Airbnbs I have stayed in over the years.

Downloaded from Airbnb website.
This is a complete listâ€”for me.
My website backend has a /coords API that can extract the location from the Airbnb listing.
This list only has one section, all entities are marked as been.

name: Cities
notes: List of major cities around the world.
Criteria for inclusion is basically that it sounds like a place people have heard of.
Other entities should have their city property set to the name of the city they're in, either manually or based on location.
The city.html page searches for all entities by page in a given city on this list.

name: Casinos
notes: Not into gambling but casinos can be fun in small doses.

name: Hamburgers
notes: For some reason I take a picture of every hamburger I eat.
My iPhone is remarkably good at identifying those pictures.

name: European Union
notes: The coutries in the European Union.
UK marked as strike after Brexit.

header: List of all EmmaÃ¼s charity shops in France.
name: EmmaÃ¼s

header: Transport museums and heritage lines.
name: Heritage Railways

header: Towns where cars are not allowed.
name: Car-Free

header: Metro stations where tracks end at bumper blocks (buffer stops) immediately after the platform.
name: Bumper Blocks
notes: Trains must change direction in the station, rather than continuing to overflow tracks.
Common in elevated stations, as well as stations contstrained by natural elements such as rivers.
Often the source of operational delays, such as at 8th Avenue.

header: Exposition centers around the world.
name: Expos
notes: Badges indicate: ğŸ’â€â™‚ï¸ = presented at a show, ğŸ–¼ï¸ = went to an art show, ğŸš— = went to a car show.

header: Land border checkpoints that I have crossed.
name: Border Posts
notes: In chronological order.
Does not count Schengen borders with no formalities.

name: Countries
notes: Complete list of all countries in the world.
Critera for inclusion is largely, does it have an emoji?
Also includes many non-self-governing territories that have an emoji, from before they stopped giving those out.
Also includes Wales and Scotland, because people in the UK call them countries and they have emoji too.
Entities have country code set to the two-letter code based on the emoji, or a countries array if they have more than one.
There is a country.html page that shows a summary of all elements in a given country.

header: Artists that have been featured by other artists in a song.
name: Featuring

header: Train stations that are no longer in service or have been demolished. For stations that were unfinished, unopened or otherwise generally useless, see Grands Travaux Inutiles.
name: Abandoned Stations
notes: This list contains a mix of metro and mainline stations.
Reference indicates the city and is optional in this list.

name: Capitals
notes: The national capital of every country.
Some countries have more than one capital for different purposes.
Also includes former capitals marked as strike.

header: A grand union is a rail junction at a four-way intersection in which trams arriving from any direction can continue in any direction. A three-quarter junction has three of the four curves, while a butterfly has curves on opposite corners.
name: Grand Unions
notes: I once accidentally found myself in Toronto, remembered something about it having grand unions, looked up what those were, went to visit two, and the rest is history.
I'll go to a city just for its grand unions.
I like discovering them by riding trams around, or looking at satellite maps.

header: Runways designated as Space Shuttle emergency landing sites.
name: Space Shuttle

header: Metro services that run express, bypassing stops served by local services.
name: Express Lines
notes: Almost exclusively a New York thing.
Baffles people from out of town.

headers: Iâ€™ve been to every station in:
name: Metros

header: Cities that have hosted the Eurovision Song Contest.
name: Eurovision
notes: Action: sort out cities that have hosted more than once. Keys are clashing.
Action: link to wiki page for the that year's contest rather than the city's wiki page.

name: DÃ©partements franÃ§ais
notes: Second and third icon form the department number.
I've been to most!
Action: figure out sorting.

header: My favortite musical artists and bands.
name: Artists

header: Cities that are officially bilingual, with street signs in several languages.
name: Bilingual
Depots
notes: Depots where metros and trams go to sleep at night.
Sometimes pulled from wikipedia, often discovered while riding trams.
I try to have coordinates for all entities.

name: Public Baths
notes: Historical city-run public baths.

name: Bi-Articulated Buses
notes: Buses that have two articulations, three sections, and four axles.
I find these endlessly fascinating.
These form the backbone of transit in BogotÃ¡, one of the most amazing BRT systems I have ever seen.
BogotÃ¡ has high-floor â€œpullerâ€ busses with the engine in the front and powered second axle.

name: Cathedrals
notes: These are mainly Roman Catholic cathedrals, with some exceptions for other denominations.
Generally listed under the name of the city, even if they are technicaly named after a saint.
Some have a more common name, such as St. Patrickâ€™s in New York.
Listed by name in cases where there is more than one per city.
Cathedral has a very specific meaning in the Catholic church, as the seat of a bishop. A few buildings that look like cathedrals but technically aren't are included.

header: A road trip around the borders of France.
name: French Borders

header: Foods that are named after places I have been.
name: Wine & Cheese
notes: The second icon is the type of food or drink.
The list focuses on wine and cheesse, but also contains a few other food and drink types as well as some tongue-in-cheek references.
Yes I've been to Latte in Italy.

header: Songs originally recorded by someone else.
name: Cover Songs
notes: Includes both the original and cover versions.
Reference is the artist.
All Along the Watchtower is my favorite cover song, original by Bob Dylan, covers by Jimi Hendrix, U2 and Dave Matthews Band.

name: Aqueducts
notes: Most of these are aqueducts that survive from the ancient world.
Names and wikipedia links are typically in local languages, i.e. acquedotto, acueducto, etc.

header: Lines that have switched from one service to another.
name: Switched Service

header: Countries and territories whose sovereignty is disputed.
name: Disputed Territories
notes: I've actually been to very few of these.
Visiting Transnistria was totally bizarre.

header: Trams that serve metro-like stations.
name: Premetros

header: Real names of musicians, actors and other celebrities.
name: Real Names
notes: Name is the person's real name, reference is their stage name.
Some artists are known by their real first name, such as Adele or Madonna, or their real last name, such as Morrissey.

header: Bands with names like â€œSiouxie and the Bansheesâ€.
name: Backing Bands
notes: Just to mix things up a bit this page focuses on the backing band as the name, with the singer as the reference.

header: Bands that have a mix of people of different races and genders.
name: Diverse Bands
notes: Badges include emoji representing the different race/gender combinations.

header: Cities that charge a toll for driving in the central zone.
name: Congestion Charge

header: The first location of popular restaurants and other chains.

header: Stations with a transfer from the end of one line to the beginning of another.
name: Head-On Connections

header: Countries that use the euro.
name: Eurozone
notes: Four microstates are not members of the ECB, but use the euro by agreement and have their own coins.
Montenegro and Kosovo use the euro unilaterally.
I was in Slovenia the day they adopted the euro.
Action: add year of adoption.

header: Cities that have a proper Bus Rapid Transit system, with dedicated lanes and stops.
name: Bus Rapid Transit

ğŸšŒ badge means I have taken BRT there.
Popular in Central and South America, such as Mexico City and BogotÃ¡.
BogotÃ¡ system was life changing.

header: Places that have dual heads of state.

header: The forty boundary stones were placed at one mile intervals around the original border of the District of Columbia in 1791. Most of them are now behind bars!
name: Boundary Stones
notes: I visited the forty stones over three days. Each one deserves a whole story.
Three of them were not reachable.

name: Architects
notes: Architects whose work I admire.
I also have a few dedicated pages for buildings by Norman Foster and Santiago Calatrava.
I am thinking of replacing this page with a list of my favorite buildings by these architects, with the name of the architect as the reference.

header: Metro stations with different names connected inside fare control.
name: Connections
notes: Russian transfer stations typically have different names for each line that passes through.
New York has many stations downtown that are connected by pedestrian passageways.
Some New York stations are named for an avenue or a street, depending upon the line (14th Street on the ACE, 8th Avenue on the L).

history: Ninteenth century predecessor of the shopping mall, like covered streets lined with shops in the middle of a block.

Bucket List

I try to keep a balance here between been and todo.
Second icon represents the type of place.

header: In 2003 we visited 27 European countries over six months, and I took 10,000 pictures. Hereâ€™s a list of where we went each day.
name: Europe 2003
notes: I wrote a Mac program called Shoebox that let you tag photos by date, place, people and things.
This list was created years later by indexing all the photos tagged by date and place.

header: Cities that have been named as European Capital of Culture.
name: Culture Capitals
notes: Action: add year for each city.

name: Santiago Calatrava

Well known for the PATH terminal at the World Trade Center, also known as the Oculus.

header: Metro systems where you can add a farecard to Apple Wallet.
name: Apple Wallet

header: Stations with curved platforms.
name: Curved Platforms
notes: Not widely tracked, mostly discovered in real life.
Stations on the London Underground with sharp curves often have significant gaps at the ends or in the middle, leading to the famous Mind the Gap warnings.
Also many in New York and Paris
Most recent metros have only straight platforms.
Does not count slight curvature as trains enter stations with island platforms, idea is that the train leaves pointing in a different direction.

header: Automobile factories by brand.
name: Factories
notes: First flag is country of the brand, second flag is location of the factory. Domestic factories have twice the same flag.

header: Metro stations that have primary names in two or more languages.
name: Bilingual Stations
notes: The criterion for inclusion is that the meaning has been translated, like Ã‰tangs Noirs / Zwarte Vijvers.
I do not include stations whose name is simply transliterated from another script.
This list is sorted by city, as it's more interesting to see these in context of where they are.
I didn't include the city as the reference because it is obvious in context and would be repetitive.

header: Cars that are named for places.
name: Car Places
notes: There are a lot more of these than you would think!

header:
Evidence of the Great Streetcar Conspiracy,
as revealed in the film Who Framed Roger Rabbit?
name: Closed Trams

name: Female Bassists
notes: Female bassists are super cool!
Wikipedia has a long list, these are just the people or bands that I'm familiar with.
Reference is the band.

header: Highways that can be used as emergency runways for military aircraft.
name: Highway Strips
Cable Cars
notes: Also known as aerial trams.
As distinct from Cable Cars in San Francisco, that's totally different.
These come in two forms: large cars that go back and forth, and smaller cars that operate in a continuous loop.
Some are used for urban transit, especially in Central and South America.
Paris recently opened CÃ¢ble 1.

header: Transit systems that are free!
name: Fare Free
notes: Prefix is year it became free.
Reference is a group of people, such as residents or young people.

header: Entire metro lines that have closed completely.
name: Closed Lines
notes: New York has a large number of closed elevanted lines.
Limited to metro lines; closed tram lines would be uncountable.

header: Stations where you can change from one line to another by walking across a platform.
name: Cross-Platform
notes: I love discovering these.
I try to be very strict about what counts.
Not including stations in New York where you can change from express to local trains on the services of the same color.

name: Canals

The Circle Line in London was converted from circular to loopback when it was extended to Hammersmith.

Some French chateaux are little more than fancy houses.

header: Anton Corbijn defined the look of many of my favorite bands. Here are some places where he photographed them.
name: Anton Corbijn
notes: He had a particularly strong influence on Depeche Mode and U2.
I went searching for the exact spot where he photographed an S-Bahn train crossing a bridge in Berlin for the cover of Achtung Baby, and recreated the photo.
I visited Joshua Tree and took a selfie similar to the cover of the U2 album.

header: Airlines that I have flown on.
name: Airlines

name: Cemeteries
notes: Sometimes it's nice to visit cemeteries as they're nice and quiet.

header: Places featured on the Accidentally Wes Anderson instagram account, website and books.
name: Accidentally Wes Anderson
notes: I bought the Accidentally Wes Anderson at the Strand bookstore and didn't even open it for a while.
I saw the Hotel BelvÃ©dÃ¨re from many kilometers away across a glacial valley and said wait, that's on the cover of this book I have!
Now I'm obsessed about visiting these places, and recreating the exact photos if possible.
I also take pictures of other places with a similar vibe.

header: Some of the deepest metro stations.
name: Deep Level
notes: I've tried to include the deepest station in each system, or stations that are known to be particularly deep.
Definitely not an exhaustive list, and there's no precise criteria for what counts.

name: Bridges
notes: Size property is the total length of the bridge in meters.
Sorted by size.

header: Intersectons of streets named Grand and Union.
name: Grand & Union
notes: Not to be confused with grand unions, which are a type of tram intersection.
I'm probably the only person in the world with this list.
I live near one in Brooklyn.
I first noticed one near a spa in New Jersey.
These are hard to find using AI. I asked an early versiob of ChatGPT for a list and it halucinated about 90 that don't exist.

header: Lines where different services run in opposite directions.
name: Opposite Lines

header: Locations of major nuclear explosions.
name: Ground Zero
notes: Name refers to the point on the ground below the point where the bomb exploded, which is air zero. Circles around it measure distance from the zero point.
I've been to ground zero in Hiroshima.
Everyone calls the World Trade Center ground zero but it doesn't fit this list.

header: Metro systems that have fare cards that let you tap to ride.
name: Fare Cards
Camping
notes: Places where I've gone camping in a tent!
I don't do this as much as I used to.
Locations are not exact, these are mostly from a while ago.

header: Buildings that are copies of other buildings.

header: A train trip to Prague, Brno, Vienna and Graz.

header: Stations or border crossings where people or cargo need to change from tracks of one gauge to another.
name: Break of Gauge
notes: I recently changed guagues at Irun / Hendaye when traveling from Spain to France.

header: Places where heavy rail tracks cross, or trams cross heavy rail tracks.
name: Diamond Crossings
notes: Named for the shape when rails cross at an angle.
Tram tracks cross each other all the time, so not included.
Mainline tracks typically merge into each other at points rather than crossing, which creates signaling challenges.
Coolest examples are when trams cross heavy rail tracks, even at different gagues.
Action: mark the tram/rail crossings.

name: Ferries
notes: Action: group by taken/visited, like metros page.

header: Stations with direct interchange between different modes of transport.
name: Intermodal

header: Structures that can be deployed to control water flow during floods.

header: Stations served more than once by the same line.
name: Loopback

header: Metro stations with only one platform edge.
name: Single Platform

header: Metro services with grade of automation level 4 (GoA4), full automation.
name: Automatic Metros
notes: Year indicates the first year that automatic trains ran in that metro system.
Been indicates whether I have taken automatic trains on that line.

header: Cities that are (or were) closed to outsiders.
name: Closed Cities
notes: Most common in the former Soviet Union.
Usually for military or scientific purposes.

header: Train systems that have unusual gauges, narrower or wider than standard gauge.
name: Track Gauges
notes: Prefix is number of millimeters.
1435 is standard gauge.
Clicking a number on the page converts it from millimeters to feet and fractional inches using a small JS function.

name: Gyms
Airports
notes: The prefix is the three-letter airport code.

name: Bisexual People
notes: Musicians and other celebrities who are known or thought to be bisexual.
Personally I have deprecated that term and prefer pansexual, as it better represents a lack of strong preference along the gender spectrum.
